verses.verse: Then Job<WH347> answered<WH6030> and said,<WH559>
I know<WH3045> it is so<WH3588> <WH3651> of a truth:<WH551> but how<WH4100> should man<WH582> be just<WH6663> with<WH5973> God?<WH410>
If <WH518> he will<WH2654> contend<WH7378> with<WH5973> him, he cannot<WH3808> answer<WH6030> him one<WH259> of<WH4480> a thousand.<WH505>
He is wise<WH2450> in heart,<WH3824> and mighty<WH533> in strength:<WH3581> who<WH4310> hath hardened<WH7185> himself against<WH413> him, and hath prospered?<WH7999>
Which removeth<WH6275> the mountains,<WH2022> and they know<WH3045> not:<WH3808> which<WH834> overturneth<WH2015> them in his anger.<WH639>
Which shaketh<WH7264> the earth<WH776> out of her place,<WH4480> <WH4725> and the pillars<WH5982> thereof tremble.<WH6426>
Which commandeth<WH559> the sun,<WH2775> and it riseth<WH2224> not;<WH3808> and sealeth up<WH2856> the stars.<WH3556>
Which alone<WH905> spreadeth out<WH5186> the heavens,<WH8064> and treadeth<WH1869> upon<WH5921> the waves<WH1116> of the sea.<WH3220>
Which maketh<WH6213> Arcturus,<WH5906> Orion,<WH3685> and Pleiades,<WH3598> and the chambers<WH2315> of the south.<WH8486>
Which doeth<WH6213> great things<WH1419> past<WH5704> <WH369> finding out;<WH2714> yea, and wonders<WH6381> without<WH5704> <WH369> number.<WH4557>
Lo, <WH2005> he goeth<WH5674> by<WH5921> me, and I see<WH7200> him not:<WH3808> he passeth on<WH2498> also, but I perceive<WH995> him not.<WH3808>
Behold, <WH2005> he taketh away,<WH2862> who<WH4310> can hinder<WH7725> him? who<WH4310> will say<WH559> unto<WH413> him, What<WH4100> doest<WH6213> thou?
If God<WH433> will not<WH3808> withdraw<WH7725> his anger,<WH639> the proud<WH7295> helpers<WH5826> do stoop<WH7817> under<WH8478> him.
How much less<WH637> <WH3588> shall I<WH595> answer<WH6030> him, and choose out<WH977> my words<WH1697> to reason with<WH5973> him?
Whom, <WH834> though<WH518> I were righteous,<WH6663> yet would I not<WH3808> answer,<WH6030> but I would make supplication<WH2603> to my judge.<WH8199>
If <WH518> I had called,<WH7121> and he had answered<WH6030> me; yet would I not<WH3808> believe<WH539> that<WH3588> he had hearkened<WH238> unto my voice.<WH6963>
For <WH834> he breaketh<WH7779> me with a tempest,<WH8183> and multiplieth<WH7235> my wounds<WH6482> without cause.<WH2600>
He will not<WH3808> suffer<WH5414> me to take<WH7725> my breath,<WH7307> but<WH3588> filleth<WH7646> me with bitterness.<WH4472>
If <WH518> I speak of strength,<WH3581> lo,<WH2009> he is strong:<WH533> and if<WH518> of judgment,<WH4941> who<WH4310> shall set me a time<WH3259> to plead?
If <WH518> I justify<WH6663> myself, mine own mouth<WH6310> shall condemn<WH7561> me: if I say, I<WH589> am perfect,<WH8535> it shall also prove me perverse.<WH6140>
Though I<WH589> were perfect,<WH8535> yet would I not<WH3808> know<WH3045> my soul:<WH5315> I would despise<WH3988> my life.<WH2416>
This <WH1931> is one<WH259> thing, therefore<WH5921> <WH3651> I said<WH559> it, He<WH1931> destroyeth<WH3615> the perfect<WH8535> and the wicked.<WH7563>
If <WH518> the scourge<WH7752> slay<WH4191> suddenly,<WH6597> he will laugh<WH3932> at the trial<WH4531> of the innocent.<WH5355>

The earth<WH776> is given<WH5414> into the hand<WH3027> of the wicked:<WH7563> he covereth<WH3680> the faces<WH6440> of the judges<WH8199> thereof; if<WH518> not,<WH3808> where,<WH645> and who<WH4310> is he?<WH1931>
Now my days<WH3117> are swifter<WH7043> than<WH4480> a post:<WH7323> they flee away,<WH1272> they see<WH7200> no<WH3808> good.<WH2896>
They are passed away<WH2498> as<WH5973> the swift<WH16> ships:<WH591> as the eagle<WH5404> that hasteth<WH2907> to<WH5921> the prey.<WH400>
If <WH518> I say,<WH559> I will forget<WH7911> my complaint,<WH7879> I will leave off<WH5800> my heaviness,<WH6440> and comfort<WH1082> myself:
I am afraid<WH3025> of all<WH3605> my sorrows,<WH6094> I know<WH3045> that<WH3588> thou wilt not<WH3808> hold me innocent.<WH5352>
If I<WH595> be wicked,<WH7561> why<WH4100> then<WH2088> labor<WH3021> I in vain?<WH1892>
If <WH518> I wash myself<WH7364> with snow<WH7950> water,<WH4325> and make my hands<WH3709> never<WH1253> so clean;<WH2141>
Yet <WH227> shalt thou plunge<WH2881> me in the ditch,<WH7845> and mine own clothes<WH8008> shall abhor<WH8581> me.
For <WH3588> he is not<WH3808> a man,<WH376> as I<WH3644> am, that I should answer<WH6030> him, and we should come<WH935> together<WH3162> in judgment.<WH4941>
Neither <WH3808> is there<WH3426> any daysman<WH3198> between<WH996> us, that might lay<WH7896> his hand<WH3027> upon<WH5921> us both.<WH8147>
Let him take his rod away<WH5493> <WH7626> from<WH4480> <WH5921> me, and let not<WH408> his fear<WH367> terrify<WH1204> me:
Then would I speak,<WH1696> and not<WH3808> fear<WH3372> him; but<WH3588> it is not<WH3808> so<WH3651> with<WH5978> me.
